children.name: to want st or want to do st
want
examples: [intransitive/transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
muốn
▪ My parents moved out of London because they wanted a bigger house.
▪ Do you want milk in your coffee?
want to do something : muốn làm gì
▪ What do you want to do at the weekend?
▪ Stacey wants to be a doctor.
want somebody to do something : muốn ai làm gì
▪ She wants Tom to come to her party.
what somebody wants is : điều ai muốn là
▪ What we want is a car that’s cheap and reliable.
if you want (to) : nếu bạn muốn ...
▪ You can go back to bed for a while if you want.

children.name: would like
children.definition: especiallyspokenuse this as apoliteway of asking for something, offering something, or saying what you want to do:

children.name: muốn ( giao tiếp lịch sự )
examples: ▪ We’d like some information about flights to Chicago, please.
▪ Would you like some more coffee?

children.name: would like to do something : muốn làm gì
examples: ▪ I’d like to reserve a room for Saturday.
▪ Would you like to borrow this book?

children.name: would like somebody to do something : muốn ai làm gì
examples: ▪ We would like you to attend an interview at 3:30 on Friday.

children.name: feel like
children.partOfSpeech: [verb phrase not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: especiallyspokento want to have something or do something, because you think you would enjoy it:

children.name: cảm thấy thích
examples: ▪ I feel like a long, hot soak in the bath.
▪ It’s a lovely day - do you feel like a walk?

children.name: feel like doing something : cảm thấy thích làm gì
examples: ▪ I feel like watching a movie tonight.

children.name: be interested in
children.definition: to think that you may want to do something, buy something, or get involved in something:

children.name: thích thú với
examples: ▪ Melanie wants to be a lawyer, and Sam’s interested in a career in teaching.

children.name: be interested in doing something : thích thú với việc gì
examples: ▪ We’re interested in buying an apartment downtown.
▪ Would you be interested in going to the theatre with me on Friday? I have two tickets for ‘The King and I’.

children.name: wouldn’t mind
children.definition: to want to do or have something, but not very strongly:
examples: ▪ I wouldn’t mind another cup of coffee. How about you?

children.name: I wouldn’t mind doing something
examples: ▪ It was a really good play. I wouldn’t mind seeing it again.

children.name: wish
children.partOfSpeech: [intransitive/transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: to want to do something
examples: ao ước
wish to do something : ao ước làm gì
▪ I wish to purchase a second house in the UK for investment purposes.
▪ Anyone wishing to order the book should send a cheque to the publishers.
if you wish : nếu bạn ao ước
▪ Everyone has the right to smoke if they wish, but not the right to ruin the health of those around them.

children.name: I wouldn’t say no
children.definition: say this when you would like to do or have something:
examples: tôi sẽ không nói không, tôi sẽ không từ chối đâu
▪ ‘How about a girls’ night out on the town?’ ‘I wouldn’t say no!’
I wouldn’t say no to :
▪ I wouldn’t say no to a glass of whisky!

children.name: fancy
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: Britishinformalto want to have or do something:

children.name: muốn
examples: ▪ Do you fancy a drink?
▪ I think he’s always fancied a car like Lizzie’s.

children.name: fancy doing something : muốn làm gì
examples: ▪ I really fancy going for a swim.

children.name: take your fancy
children.definition: if something takes your fancy, you want to do or have itas soon as you see it or think of it:

children.name: muốn ( ngay khi nhìn thấy hay nghĩ đến )
examples: ▪ We could go to the movies or go out for a meal -- whatever takes your fancy.
▪ She wandered around the market stalls, stopping occasionally to look at something that took her fancy.

children.name: wish
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: to want somethingto happen, when it isunlikelyorimpossiblethat it will happen, or when youcannot controlwhat will happen:
examples: ước ( điều gì xảy ra nhưng sự thật không thể xảy ra )
wish (that)
▪ I wish I had a car like that.
▪ Beth wished she could stay there forever.
wish somebody/something would do something : ước ai / điều gì làm gì/ xảy ra
▪ I wish they would turn that music down.

children.name: would love
children.definition: especiallyspokento want something very much, and feel that you would be happy if you had it:
examples: rất muốn
▪ I would love a cup of coffee.
would love to do something : rất muốn làm gfi
▪ She would love to have children, but she hasn’t met the right man.
▪ ‘Would you like to go on a Caribbean cruise?’ ‘I’d love to!’
would love somebody to do something : rất muốn ai làm gì
▪ My mother would love me to come and live in New York with her.

children.name: can’t wait
children.definition: say this when you want something to happen as soon as possible, because you know you will enjoy it and you are very excited about it:
examples: không thể chờ đợi , kìm hãm được
▪ ‘You’re going on holiday soon, aren’t you?’ ‘Yes, I can’t wait.’
I can’t wait to do something : không thể kìm hãm được làm gì
▪ I can’t wait to see Bill again - it’s been a long time.
can’t wait for : không thể chờ đợi , kìm hãm được cho
▪ I can’t wait for Christmas.

children.name: be dying
children.definition: to want something very much, and feel that you must have it or do itimmediately:
examples: khao khát
be dying to do something : khao khát làm gì
▪ I’m dying to meet Lisa’s new boyfriend.
be dying for : khao khát cái gì
▪ I’m dying for a drink - let’s go to a bar.

children.name: would give anything/would give your right arm
children.definition: if you say that you would do anything, would give anything or would give your right arm,you mean you very much want to have something or do something, especially something that isimpossibleto get or do:
examples: sẽ làm bất cứ điều gì ( để có được gì, làm gì, đặc biệt điều đó không thể xảy ra )
would do anything/would give anything/would give your right arm for
▪ I would do anything for a drink right now!
▪ I would give anything for a look at that file.
woulddo anything/would give anything/would give your right arm to do something
▪ When she first started writing, she would have done anything to get an article printed.
▪ I’d give my right arm to be 21 again.

children.name: be eager to do st also
children.definition: be eager to do somethingalsobe keen to do somethingBritish   to want to do something very much, especially because you think it will beinterestingorenjoyableor it willhelpother people:

children.name: muốn , tha thiết ( vì thấy nó thú vị hay có thể giúp người khác )
examples: ▪ He’s really keen to meet you.
▪ I was eager to get my hands on these rare recordings.
▪ Donna is very eager to prove her worth to the group.

children.name: be keen for somebody to do something : muốn, tha thiết ai làm gì
examples: ▪ My parents were keen for me to be independent, and let me have a lot of freedom.

children.name: be dying
children.definition: to want something very much, and feel that you must have it or do it immediately:

children.name: be dying to do something
examples: ▪ I’m dying to meet Lisa’s new boyfriend.

children.name: be dying for
examples: ▪ I’m dying for a drink - let’s go to a bar.

children.name: be anxious to do st
children.definition: be anxious to do something  to want very much to do or achieve something, so that you make a great effort:
examples: da diết, tha thiết, khắc khoải muốn làm gì
▪ Miles was anxious to gain his boss’s approval, and was always the last to leave the office in the evening.
▪ A newly-arrived executive is usually anxious to make his mark in a new firm.
be anxious for somebody/something to do something
da diết, tha thiết, khắc khoải muốn ai làm gì / điều gì xảy ra
▪ After the war, the government was anxious for the tourist industry to be revived.

children.name: be desperate
children.definition: especially British to want or need something so much that you will be veryunhappyordisappointedif you do not get it:

children.name: khao khát
examples: ▪ I could see that they were desperate and needed help.

children.name: be desperate to do something
examples: ▪ After having four boys, the couple were desperate to have a little girl.
▪ We were desperate to view the inside of the house once we saw the garden.

children.name: be desperate for
examples: ▪ Newspapers are always desperate for stories.

children.name: be itching to do st
children.definition: be itching to do something  to be impatient to do something that you are excited about, especially something you havenot donebefore:

children.name: rất muốn ( làm gì mà trước đó chưa từng làm )
examples: ▪ She’s just itching to tell you about her new boyfriend.
▪ Despite her success, however, it just wasn’t much fun anymore. Liz was itching to try something different.

children.name: need
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: a word used especially inspokenEnglish meaning to want something very much, especially something to eat, drink etc:

children.name: cần
examples: ▪ I need a drink - coming to the bar?
▪ Dave’s been working really hard - he needs a holiday.

children.name: crave
children.definition: to want as much of something as you can get, especially food, attention, or a drug:

children.name: khao khát ( muốn có nhiều nhất có thể )
examples: ▪ I’ve always craved love and acceptance.
▪ The review gave Picasso a taste of the recognition he craved.

children.name: to not want to do or have st
not want
examples: not want to do something
▪ She doesn’t want to see me anymore.
▪ We asked him to come with us, but he said he didn’t want to.
not want somebody to do something
▪ ‘Why didn’t he tell me he was sick?’ ‘He didn’t want you to worry.’

children.name: not feel like
children.definition: doing something  especially spoken to not want to do something, especially because you think you would not enjoy it or because you feel too lazy:
examples: ▪ I don’t feel like writing that essay today.
▪ Some days she just doesn’t feel like going to work.

children.name: I’d rather not
children.definition: say this when you do not want to do something, especially because you think it maycause problems for you:

children.name: không muốn ( vì sợ có thể gây rắc rối cho bản thân )
examples: ▪ I could lend him the money, but to be honest, I’d rather not.

children.name: I’d rather not do something
examples: ▪ I’d rather not talk about it right now.

children.name: be unwilling to do st
children.definition: be unwilling to do something formalto not want to do something, even though youshoulddo it orsomeone wantsyou to do it:

children.name: không sẵn lòng
examples: ▪ She is unwilling to admit that she was wrong.
▪ Most people here are unwilling to give up their cars and use buses and trains instead.

children.name: have no desire to do sth
children.definition: have no desire to do something formalto not want to do something, especially something that you are beingaskedorforcedto do:

children.name: không ao ước làm gì ( được yêu cầu, ép buộc )
examples: ▪ Sarah had been to Harlow before, and had no desire to go there again.
▪ Richards tried to enlist my support, but I had no desire to get involved.

children.name: you are welcome to sth
children.definition: you are welcome to something/you can keep somethinginformalyou say that someoneiswelcometo something when you do not like it and you are happy for them to have it instead of you:

children.name: bạn có thể có nó, giữ nó
examples: ▪ She’s welcome to her smart friends and glittering parties -- I’ll take the quiet life anytime.
▪ He can keep his money -- he’s not going to bribe me!

children.name: I’d rather die
children.definition: use this to say strongly that you really do not want to do something that someone hassuggestedormentioned:

children.name: tôi muốn chết ( hàm ý tôi không muốn làm những gì bạn đề cập, đề nghị )
examples: ▪ Apologize to that creep! I’d rather die!

children.name: a feeling that you want to do or have st
desire
children.definition: especially written a strong feeling of wanting to have something or wanting to do something, especially something important, which makes you try very hard to have it or do it:
examples: sự thèm muốn , lòng khao khát
desire to do something : sự khát khao làm gì
▪ Young children have a keen desire to learn and succeed.
desire for : sự khát khao cho
▪ After so many years of war, there was a great desire for peace.
a strong/keen/burning desire : một khát khao cháy bỏng
▪Young Peryoux left home for Paris, armed with a guitar, and a burning desire to succeed.

children.name: wish
children.definition: something that you want to happen, especially when this is very important to you:

children.name: ước muốn
examples: ▪ His last wish was that his body should be buried in his home town.

children.name: somebody’s dearest/greatest wishthe thing they want most of all : ước muốn lớn nhất
examples: ▪ She always wanted to see her grandchildren again - it was her dearest wish.

children.name: longing/yearning
children.definition: a very strong and long-lasting desire for something that you are unlikely to get - used especially instoriesandliterature:
examples: niềm khát khát, ham muốn ( dùng trong truyện, văn chương )
longing/yearning for
▪ She felt a great longing for the sights, sounds and smells of home.
▪ The story gives a sensitive account of Paul’s innocent yearning for love and affection.
longing/yearning to do something
▪ At 18 I had a strong yearning to leave my small town, and see the world.

children.name: craving
children.definition: a very strong anduncontrollabledesire to have something that you think about all the time, especially food, attention, or a drug:

children.name: cơn thèm, sự khao khát
examples: ▪ After a week without smoking, the craving began to disappear.

children.name: craving for
examples: ▪ The symptoms include a craving for sweet foods.

children.name: lust
children.definition: a very strong desire to have something, such as money or power, that can make you doevil thingsto get what you want:
examples: sự thèm khát ( bất chấp việc xấu để có được )
lust for
▪ Throughout his career he was motivated by a lust for power.
▪ Her lust for money is insatiable.

children.name: appetite
children.definition: a strong desire to have somethingregularlyor do something regularly:
examples: sự ham muốn ( thường xuyên )
appetite for
▪ He has a tremendous appetite for hard work.
insatiable appetite
extremely strong appetite
▪ The public has an insatiable appetite for scandal and political controversy.
whet somebody’s appetitemake it stronger
▪ The dangers of the climb up Mt. Washington only whetted our appetite for more adventure.

children.name: temptation
children.definition: a strong desire to do something, even though you know it iswrong,dangerous,unnecessaryetc:
examples: sự cám dỗ ( dù biết xấu, nguy hiểm, ko cần thiết )
temptation to do something cưong
▪ There is always a temptation to blame others for your own problems.
resist the temptation :cưỡng lại cám dỗ
not do something, even though you want to
▪ Resist the temptation to get involved. After all, it’s not your problem.
give in to temptationto do something, after trying not to :
bị khuất phục trước cơn cám dỗ
▪ In the end, he gave in to temptation, and lit his first cigarette in five days.

children.name: compulsion
children.definition: an extremely strong desire, usually anunreasonableone, that isdifficultorimpossibleto control:

children.name: sự cưỡng ép , cưỡng bách ( khiến bạn không thể kìm chế được )
examples: ▪ The patient had a compulsion that caused him to wash his hands 20 or 30 times a day.

children.name: compulsion to do something
examples: ▪ He felt a sudden compulsion to laugh out loud.

children.name: to want st very much and be determined to get it
set your sights on
children.definition: to decide that you want something that will be hard for you to get, and to make a very determined effort to achieve it:

children.name: hạ quyết tâm
examples: ▪ Now she’s set her sights on the manager’s job, nothing will stop her.
▪ Quite consciously, I set my sights on the best-looking boy in the whole school.

children.name: set your heart on
children.definition: to want something so much that you will be very disappointed if you cannot have it or get it:

children.name: hạ quyết tâm
examples: ▪ We’ve set our hearts on this little house in the country.

children.name: set your heart on doing something : hạ quyết tâm làm gì
examples: ▪ I had set my heart on becoming a pilot.

children.name: to want st that you are very unlikely to get
dream of
children.definition: to want something that you have wanted for a long time, but which you are unlikely to get:

children.name: mơ ước
examples: ▪ It was the kind of house I’d always dreamed of having.
▪ To think that what I’ve dreamt of all my life is coming true!

children.name: dream of doing something : mơ ước làm gì
examples: ▪ She dreamt of becoming a famous novelist.
▪ Every jazz-lover at some time of his life has dreamed of assembling a band of his own favourite musicians.

children.name: long
children.definition: to very much want to have something or do something, especially when this used to happen or exist in the past, or when it may do in the future - used especially instoriesorliterature:
examples: nóng lòng, mong mỏi, ước ao ( thường trong truyện, văn học )
long for
▪ He longed for the good old days when teachers were shown respect.
▪ He was longing for everyone to leave, so that he could think in peace about what had happened that day.
long to do something
▪ More than anything, I long to have someone who loves me for myself.
longed-for/ˈlɒŋd fɔːʳǁˈlɔːŋd-/ [adjective only before noun]được mong đợi
▪ The day of the longed-for visit that people had been longing for eventually arrived.

children.name: yearn
children.definition: to want something so much that you do not feel happy or complete without it:

children.name: nóng lòng, mong mỏi, ước ao
examples: yearn for : nóng lòng, mong mỏi, ước ao có được ...
▪ The people yearned for peace, and the chance to rebuild their shattered lives.
▪ Hannah yearned for a child, and felt desperately sad whenever she saw other women with their babies.

children.name: yearn to do something : nóng lòng, mong mỏi, ước ao làm gì
examples: ▪ I have always yearned to travel.

children.name: hanker after/for something
children.definition: to want something that you are unlikely to get very much, especiallysecretly, and over along periodof time:

children.name: nóng lòng, mong mỏi, ước ao ( thầm kín )
examples: ▪ Paula had always hankered after a traditional white wedding.
▪ I had a good job and a nice apartment, but I still hankered for the country life.

children.name: to have an aim in life that you want to achieve
want
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive verb not in progressive or passive]

children.name: to be something : muốn trởi thành gì
examples: ▪ What do you want to be when you grow up, Clare?
▪ You don’t really want to be a hairdresser, do you?

children.name: to do something : muốn làm gì
examples: ▪ I never want to work in a factory, having seen the effect it had on my father.
▪ I want to see life, to travel the world, and write about what I see.

children.name: aspire to
children.definition: to want a better job, way of life, position etc than the one you have now:

children.name: khao khát, tham vọng, mong muốn ( có được điều gì tốt hơn hiện tại )
examples: ▪ She was a struggling writer aspiring to fame.
▪ He aspired to artistic perfection in all his paintings.

children.name: aspire to do something
examples: ▪ He aspired to become President.

children.name: would-be
children.definition: alsowannabeinformal

children.name: aspiring
examples: aspiring teacher/model/poet etc : someone who wants to be a teacher, model, poet etc and is just starting work or training:
( ai đó muốn làm nghề gì ) nhiều tham vọng
▪ a part-time course for aspiring chefs
▪ Like a lot of aspiring New York artists, Lara worked in bars and restaurants in the evenings.

children.name: a sudden feeling of wanting sth
urge
children.definition: a sudden strong feeling that you want to do something, especially a feeling that is difficult to control:
examples: sự thôi thúc, ham muốn
urge to do something
▪ She was seized with the urge to drag Alice from her chair and shake her.
feel/have an urge
▪ I felt a sudden urge to tell him all my problems.
fight an urgetry not to do something : cưỡng lại sự thôi thúc
▪ He was fighting the urge to drink as he waited for her to come down.
resist an urgenot do something, even though you want to : cưỡng lại được sự thôi thúc
▪ Sheena resisted the urge to get in her car and go home.

children.name: whim
children.definition: a sudden feeling that you would like to do something, especially when this is notsensibleor when there isno reasonat all to do it:
examples: ý thích chợt nảy ra
▪ I don’t know why I bought it. I suppose it was just a whim.
do something on a whim : làm gì vì chợt cảm thấy thích
do something because you feel a whim
▪ I went to visit her on a whim.

children.name: impulse
children.definition: a sudden strong desire to do something before thinking aboutwhetherit is therightorsensiblething to do:

children.name: sự thôi thúc
examples: ▪ My first impulse was to go straight to Henry and tell him my news, but on reflection I thought better of it.
▪ He has to learn to control his violent impulses.

children.name: on (an) impulsebecause you feel an impulse
examples: ▪ It was an outfit that I had bought on impulse, and never worn.

children.name: st that you do not want
undesirable
children.definition: something that is undesirable is not wanted because it could affect a person or situation in a bad way:

children.name: phiền phức , không mong muốn
examples: ▪ The drug is effective, but has undesirable side effects, and long-term use can result in liver damage.

children.name: undesirable consequences/effects
examples: ▪ The incident could have undesirable consequences for the government.
▪ Environmentalists claim that the development will have undesirable effects on animal habitats in the area.

children.name: unwanted
children.definition: use this about something that youare givenor thathappens to youthat you do not want and did not ask for:

children.name: không mong muốn
examples: ▪ There are several ways that you can remove unwanted hair, including waxing or electrolysis at a salon.
▪ Jones claimed that the President made unwanted sexual advances towards her, in a Little Rock hotel room.

children.name: unwanted pregnancy : cái thai không mong muốn
examples: ▪ The pill was once expected to limit the number of unwanted pregnancies, but instead the number has soared.

children.name: unwelcome
children.definition: likely toupsetorcauseproblemsfor someone and therefore not wanted:

children.name: không được chào đón
examples: ▪ Philippides returned with the unwelcome news that the army would not be ready to march for several days.

children.name: unwelcome publicity/attention
examples: ▪ Environmentalists had been drawing unwelcome attention to the discharge of radioactive waste from nuclear power-stations.

children.name: unwelcome intruder/intrusion
examples: ▪ Many people saw the immigrants as unwelcome intruders in their town.

children.name: unwelcome visitors/guests/callers
examples: ▪ Time is precious enough, without having to cope with unwanted visitors.
